title: For a good introduction to probability theory, as well as its use in gambling, see
Taking Chances: Winning with Probability, Second Edition, Oxford University Press. A slightly more technical treatment of similar material is: Packel, Edward
The Mathematics of Games and Gambling, New Mathematical Library (Mathematical Association of America). More technically mathematical works for the advanced reader include: Feller
An Introduction to Probability Theory and Its Applications
Probability and Random Processes
Probability Theory: The Logic of Science
Theory of Probability

container-title: Frequency and Reasonable Expectation, American Journal of Physics
title: A must-read book for anyone seriously interested in the Bayesian interpretation of probability, especially those in oppositions, is: Jaynes
Probability Theory: The Logic of Science, Cambridge University Press. The derivation of probability theory as the method of inductive logic is Cox, R.T
Probability
Various philosophical approaches to probability in the philosophy of science are discussed in
Logical Foundations of Probability
The Continuum of Inductive Methods
The Logic of Scientific Discovery

publisher: Second Edition, University of Chicago Press
title: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
Against Method: Outline of an Anarchistic Theory of Knowledge

note: Popper and After: Four Modern Irrationalists, Pergamon Press. N5O Randomness
title: Farewell to Reason, Verso. These are scrutinized by: Stove
Random Walks and Random Environments

container-title: Macroirreversibility and Microreversibility Reconciled: The Second Law, in Maximum Entropy in Action
title: A much more thorough account of the history of thermodynamics than I have been able to give here is presented in

Foundations of Statistical Mechanics, Reidel, Dordrecht. The following are two excellent vigourous polemics about the meaning of entropy. I have drawn substantially from both of them, but they are much more detailed than the brief sketch I have presented here: Garrett, Anthony J.M
Some Misconceptions about Entropy
The following two papers are absolute classics of lucidity
Gibbs vs Boltzmann Entropies
A Mathematical Theory of Communication
Two fundamental papers on quantum entanglement are: Aspect, Alain et al
Experimental Test of Bell’s Inequalities Using Time-Varying Analyzers
On the Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen Paradox
Fascinating and historically important ideas on the interpretation of quantum mechanics are contained in
Causality and Chance in Modern Physics

note: Quantum Physics: Illusion or Reality? Cambridge University Press.
title: Wholeness and the Implicate Order, Routledge. An account of quantum theory steeped in multiversalist doctrine is presented in
The Fabric of Reality, Penguin Books. More even-handed accounts of the subject are: Rae, Alastair
The Mystery of the Quantum World, Adam Hilger. First steps to a Bayesian interpretation of quantum probability are outlined in
Quantum Probabilities as Bayesian Probabilities
A beautifully written overview of superstrings that shows with admirable clarity how little there is to back up the theory is presented in

note: on which this Chapter is partly based, see: Coles, P.
title: For a concise and simplified introduction to modern cosmology, including inflation

Cosmology: A Very Short Introduction, Oxford University Press. There are very many other introductions to cosmology available, including Jo Silk’s The Big Bang and Craig Hogan’s The Little Book of the Big Bang. For a technical survey of the latest observational and theoretical developments in the field
The State of the Universe
The review paper about cosmic density referred to in the text is
The Case for an Open Universe

container-title: Dirac’s Cosmology and Mach’s Principle, Nature
note: Particularly important original papers on this subject are: Dicke, R.H.
title: A Bayesian approach to the flatness problem is presented in
Getting the Measure of the Flatness Problem, Classical and Quantum Gravity, 12, L93–L98. The most comprehensive account of the different types of Anthropic Principle is
The Anthropic Cosmological Principle

container-title: Confrontation of Cosmological Theories with Observation ed
title: Large Number Coincidences and the Anthropic Principle in Cosmology
The Anthropic Principle and the Structure of the Physical World
A discussion of the Bayesian aspects of the Weak Anthropic Principle is given in
Bayesian Inductive Inference and the Anthropic Cosmological Principle

note: A slightly different version is contained in: Gott, J. Richard,
title: A nice introduction to the possibilities and probabilities that there might be life elsewhere is
Life in the Universe, Addison-Wesley. The Doomsday argument is discussed by
Is the end of the World Nigh?
Implications of the Copernican Principle for our Future Prospects

note: Our Final Century, Arrow Books. N 11 O Summing Up
title: For a wonderfully written, cogently argued and deeply pessimistic outlook on our survival as a species, see
